comments.commentBody: @ Doug Terry: You have it backwards: Penn State, being complicit in the commission of a crime (by hiding that crime from the Law), likely DID commit a crime!  Its officers and directors are to held accountable at some later time.  Please read up on the facts.  You don't need to be a lawyer to know this.
It's not their fault, the team, that is. That's going too far, although the importance of football needs to be examined in this country.
"Organizations" were not involved, individuals were.

I have seen a photograph that is a following moment  to the one in Slide 7. In it the man who is dragging the soldier to safety has his hand gently on the injured man's arm; he as a bloddy bandage around his head and seems unconscious. The other soldier is on the radio seeking help. Four courageous men are in danger; three are soldiers; the other is Joao Silva who has taken both shots.

For Heaven's sweet sake, this absolutely stunning series should be taken on the road! I have followed this work, and other similar work presented in LENS and elsewhere, for years, and this is as good as any conflict photography in history. People like Hicks, Silva, and Addario are geniuses, and (as Silva hoped) have succeded beyond any measure in presenting an aspect of the human condition to those of us who haven't been there. Any photo gallery or museum in North America would wait in line to host such an exhibit. It is brilliant, historic work and deserves an audience everywhere.
Rebecca, it's great to see your work and words again, so beautifully present here.

i believe the resignation of the President of Penn State and the actions of the board concerning Paterno are clear evidence about the 'code of silence'  that was standard procedure. To suggest that "Penn State did not commit the crime' further reflects the administration's and the athletic department's abdication of responsibility in protecting youth. Shameful!

Shel,

You're a good person not to want to leave anyone behind.
This situation is so upsetting.

KP
There was no excuse for those who knew yet ignored it. Let's remember who the victims are in this crime and that Sandusky is a criminal; sick, yes, but a criminal.

No earthly justice for these crimes, merely relief that this person has been exposed for the sordid, vile human being he is and will no longer be able to victimize others as he spends the remainder of his abhorrent life behind bars.
It's not over yet for his wife.

The solution to the complexity and understandability of health insurance information isn't giving more people access to the federal health plans (which are just as complex as other plans), but asking health plans and employers to apply health literacy and financial literacy techniques. These techniques include using everyday language, numbers and concepts familiar to non-experts; focusing on the most essential information first; making  critical action steps and behaviors clear; and providing information in multiple formats so that people have choices about how they can get information. All healthcare staff, including health plan staff, who interact with patients, families, caregivers and beneficiaries should be trained in health literacy techniques so they can deliver information more clearly and effectively.

In a way you are right. Insurance companies "negotiate" (dictate) volume discounts with providers. However, I have found that I myself have been able to negotiate a somewhat lower fee whenever I have been bulled for services not covered by insurance for various reasons.
I mean to say "billed" for services but I suppose that "bulled" is good too!
Why should heirs be family? There's a lot of room for imagination and tax deductions here in addition to reducing estate size.
perhaps amendola didn't think he deserved less jail time...perhaps he thought he was guilty.

Unable to respond to Norris on Nat Gas for autos. Pls forward. Why not use propane as an emergency fuel for natgas powered cars.Available at most supermarkets. Know it will work. Friend in the propane business offered to adapt my car to propane in 1974. Ran his trucks on propane. Short term solution until we have infrastucture to fuel with LNG.

@msf: Completely forgot about foreign travel. One of the reasons why I eventually took a card with a fee (which I haven't named: It's a Priority Club Visa, administered by Chase) was not only the link to the resort we have an ownership interest in in Mexico, but one of the key reasons I chose to take a card with an annual fee is that this card has NO FOREIGN TRANSACTION FEES. Eight days in Mexico, and we almost covered the annual fee, considering what the foreign fees have been juiced up to by the banks.
We have relatives in Scotland, England and Greece, and we hope to save on trips to see them, too.

While some Discover 5% bonus categories are limited to $300, others (the first three quarters of this year, for example) the bonus categories have been on $1500 in spending (potential rebate of $75/qtr), and there was an additional throw-in of $300 in groceries in May alone. It requires some attention, but maximizing these rebates can be done.

Indeed "that" money is ordinarily subject to the income tax (although there are income-tax free ways to obtain assets, such as with tax-free bonds or appreciating real-estate that is never sold, only passed from generation to generation).

The theory behind the estate tax is that (since we all know wealth begets wealth) dynastic wealth is better redistributed rather than concentrated in families. Like it or not, wealth equals influence. Dynasties may or may not be good for society but in the US we do not appreciate aristocracy and our laws reflect a choice to prevent one.

The gift tax is simply a necessary adjunct to the estate tax since an estate tax without a gift tax is easily avoidable by a deathbed gift.

I just finally got around to renting the movie "The Help," and I couldn't help but think that the "American people" that Romney is so fond of talking about are the new help. We are here to vote to make sure that our masters have lower taxes, that we fight their wars for non-existent WMD, that we tend their mega Wal-Marts for minimum wage, that we look the other way when they want our medicare and social security too.

We are here to anoint their child bearing wives who speak with indignance in their $1000 tee shirts when we point out that "motherhood" is not the end all in terms of accomplishment.

We are the patient help, waiting to hear if they have ever transcended their self-indulgent, self-absorbed world to fulfill anything other then their own ends. And their ends justify the means and they always will.
At least he is consistent, because he can afford medical care so should everyone else. His answer to the poor or middleclass aspiring to college-go to cheap one and borrow money from your parents.
I think Romney's take on the world is that everyone else should work for him and his cronies, for whatever he and his cronies feel like paying, because that is the way to rebuild America.

Soldiers are tired and worn out after 11 years in Afghanistan and Bush's useless war in Iraq. Soldiers don't want to go for a 5th, 6th or 7th deployment. Romney's big casino owner donor has given him 10 million dollars and wants a war with Iran badly. Now Romney says the immigrants, mostly Latinos, can stay if they join the Army. Romney has mentioned war with Iran in the past. Why is he trying to plump up the military with young immigrants? Interesting how someone who has never been in the military and has 5 sons who have never been in the military, thinks the military is the answer for everyone else.

To Susan  - Maybe we can be fooled, but we all need to be hyper-vigilant. That doesn't mean over protective - but we do need to be alert and maintain good communications with our children at all times.
Lynn, if he did not do the little you say he did, his trial may never have happened. I'm thankful he had what bravery he did.
From a fellow Penn Stater, you are absolutely correct. Thank you and God bless.

Walking out and not doing anything is not an option. He was 28 years old when that happened.
McQueary was a coward. Think of the initial hope that boy felt when he knew he was going to be rescued by McQueary. Then the despair when he realized McQueary walked out.
The only possible excuse for freezing up as he claimed he did is having his own prior abuse triggered by that event and even if that was the case any victim would have called the real police asap.
Since he has not said he was abused we can safely assume he is a self serving coward.
This happened at Penn state, not in a vacuum so don't try to deny the effect of environment on people's actions.
